title: [BUG] logic in check_equal_time_index to make sure the first index is contained in all other indices is reversed
body:
**Describe the bug**
The [sktime docs](https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/examples/01_forecasting.html) say that:

> Most forecasters that can deal with exogeneous time series will assume that the time indices of X passed to fit are a super-set of the time indices in y passed to fit 

Thus, I assume that `check_equal_time_index` with `mode='contains'` is used to make sure that the index of y is contained in the index of X. I am also running under the assumption that y as in the time series data we are trying to model is meant to be passed first to the function and all exogenous inputs afterward (like it is used in the [check_y_X function]).(https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/sktime/utils/validation/forecasting.py)). However the logic in the function seems to be reversed.

Shouldn't the line `failure_cond = not y_index.isin(first_index).all()` be switched to `failure_cond = not first_index.isin(y_index).all()`

**To Reproduce**
The following code is erroneously accepted (no error raised). Here X is a subset of y and thus should fail.
```
from sktime.utils.validation.series import check_equal_time_index

y = pd.DataFrame(data={'a':[1,1]}, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(['2005-01-01', '2005-01-02']))
X = pd.DataFrame(data={'a':[1]}, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(['2005-01-01']))

check_equal_time_index(y,X, mode='contains')
```

Here X is a superset of y but it throws an error when it shouldn't.

```
y = pd.DataFrame(data={'a':[1]}, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(['2005-01-01']))
X = pd.DataFrame(data={'a':[1,1]}, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(['2005-01-01','2005-01-02']))

check_equal_time_index(y,X, mode='contains')
```

If my understanding is correct, the fix should be just that line I mentioned.
